Hi all,

On 30 ao=C3=BBt 2013, at 02:42, <kstanley@...> <kstanley=
@...> wrote:
> I have one other random/unrelated suggestion for f=
uture SharpNEAT releases.  Of course I am not meaning to demand something, =
but just to give you something that may or may not inspire you in the futur=
e:  In our group and others multiobjective optimization is increasingly bei=
ng used in combination with NEAT and neuroevolution.  As mentioned in prior=
 discussions in this group, if you wrap NEAT with NSGA II (the multiobjecti=
ve evolutionary algorithm) then you can pretty much get away with substitut=
ing a "genetic diversity" objective (which uses historical markings to comp=
ute distances as in regular NEAT) for traditional NEAT-style speciation and=
 get similar results to original NEAT.  But the main motivation for having =
a multiobjective framework is you can combine different reward schemes.  Fo=
r example, the novelty search+local competition (NSLC) algorithm from Joel =
Lehman and myself makes novelty one objective and local competition another=
 (and genetic diversity a third).  Of course many people on this group have=
 done other great stuff with multiple objectives.  Anyway, having that abil=
ity opens up a lot of room to play with ideas, so it would be cool if some =
future SharpNEAT came with a user-friendly framework for specifying a set o=
f multiple objectives.  Just daydreaming for the future :)

I fully agree w=
ith Ken on this point.

Moving the genetic diversity of NEAT to an objectiv=
e and implementing a classic MOEA (like NSGA-II) would allow people to easi=
ly experiment with many recent ideas like novelty search & objective [1], b=
ehavioral diversity & objective [2], connection costs & objectives [3], beh=
avioral diversity & objective & transferability [4,5], diversity & objectiv=
e & reactivity, objective & generalization [6],, etc. And, of course all th=
e papers that Ken just cited.

In short, implementing a multi-objective ver=
sion of NEAT would make a lot easier to experiment with different selective=
 pressures, which is a promising avenue of research. We did this in our own=
 EC framework (http://sferes2.isir.upmc.fr but NEAT is not fully released y=
et) but our NEAT implementation is not very mature.

1. Mouret, J.-B. Novel=
ty-based Multiobjectivization. in Proceedings of IROS Workshop =E2=80=9CExp=
loring New Horizons in the Evolutionary Design of Robots=E2=80=9D 139=E2=80=
=93154 (Springer, 2009).
2. Mouret, J.-B. & Doncieux, S. Encouraging Behavi=
oral Diversity in Evolutionary Robotics: an Empirical Study. Evolutionary C=
omputation 20, 91=E2=80=93133 (2012).
3. Clune, J., Mouret, J.-B. & Lipson,=
 H. The evolutionary origins of modularity. Proceedings of the Royal Societ=
y B: Biological Sciences 280, 20122863 (2013).
4. Koos, S., Mouret, J.-B. &=
 Doncieux, S. The Transferability Approach=E2=80=AF: Crossing the Reality G=
ap in Evolutionary Robotics. IEEE Transaction on Evolutionary Computation 1=
, 1=E2=80=9325 (2011).
5. Koos, S. Cully, A. & Mouret, J.-B. Fast resilienc=
e in Robotics with the T-Resilience algorithm. International Journal of Rob=
otics Research. (2013). 
6. Pinville, T., Koos, S., Mouret, J.-B.  & Doncie=
ux, S. How to Promote Generalisation in Evolutionary Robotics: the ProGAb A=
pproach. in GECCO=E2=80=9911: Proceedings of the 13th annual conference on =
Genetic and evolutionary computation ACM, publisher 259=E2=80=93266 (2011).=


.. and many others!

Best regards,
-- 
Jean-Baptiste Mouret
